description.hltext_display: Saratoga shorts: Saratoga Foothill Club hosts four-part lecture series on Post Impressionist painters
description.content:
Foothill Club presents art lecture series
The Saratoga Foothill Club is hosting a four-part lecture series on "The Post Impressionists--Bridge to the Modern." The series will be held on Jan. 12 and 26, and Feb. 9 and 23 at 7:30 p.m. at the Saratoga Foothill Club, 20399 Park Place.
The four-part series will explore the innovative art of the Post Impressionist painters and will trace how their ideas led to the artistic styles of the 20th century.
Tickets cost $80 for the four lectures. Individual lecture tickets cost $25 at the door. For more information, call 408.867.9048 or visit www.foothillclub.org.
Music club hosts young artist award auditions
The San Jose Music Study Club is hosting the 2011 Young Artist Award Auditions; the winner will go home with a $1,000 first-place prize. Twenty musicians, whether vocalists, pianists and instrumentalists, will be chosen for 15-minute auditions on Feb. 13 from 12:30 to 5:30 p.m. at West Valley College, 14000 Fruitvale Ave.
Winners will be presented in a concert on April 16.
For more information, visit www.sjmsc.org.
Classical music orchestra hosts free concert
The Saratoga Symphony will be hosting a free concert on Jan. 16 from 3 to 5 p.m. at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, 13601yld_mgr.place_ad_here("adPosBox"); Saratoga Ave. The classical music orchestra concert includes a number of works, such as "In the Steppes of Central Asia" by Borodin and Piano Concerto, Op.2 by Arensky.
Conductor Jason Klein will talk about each program piece before it is performed. Saratoga Symphony is composed of 45 local performers who participate for the love of music and educational benefits for the community.

description.hltext_display: MorphoSys erreicht siebten klinischen Meilenstein in 2010
description.content:
Martinsried (aktiencheck.de AG) - Der Biotechnologiekonzern MorphoSys AG (ISIN DE0006632003 / WKN 663200) gab am Mittwoch den Erhalt einer klinischen Meilensteinzahlung von der Centocor Ortho Biotech Inc. bekannt, die durch die Beantragung einer klinischen Phase 1-Studie mit einem HuCAL-basierten Antikörper im Bereich entzündliche und Autoimmunerkrankungen ausgelöst wurde. Mit dieser Nachricht erzielt MorphoSys den siebten klinischen Meilenstein des Jahres.
Wie das Unternehmen mitteilte, umfasst seine klinische Pipeline nun neun Partnerprogramme in der Phase 1 und fünf Programme in Phase 2 sowie die firmeneigenen Entwicklungsprogramme MOR103, das sich in einer Phase 1b/2a-Studie in rheumatoider Arthritis befindet und MOR208, das eine Phase 1-Studie im Bereich chronische lymphatische Leukämie durchläuft.
Die Aktie von MorphoSys schloss gestern mit einem Minus von 0,16 Prozent bei 18,23 Euro. (22.12.2010/ac/n/t)

description.hltext_display: 1,150 will work to build on Hemlock plant in Clarksville
description.content:
CLARKSVILLE, Tenn. Officials say 1,150 workers are being employed to build a polysilicon plant in Clarksville, and that number is expected to increase. The $1.2 billion Hemlock Semiconductor facility is scheduled to be finished in 2012, with production expected to start later that year.
Meanwhile, officials say the construction work force at the site is expected to peak at 1,500 by the middle of next year.
Hemlock has also started a training program for production operators.
Michigan-based Hemlock Semiconductor is a joint venture between Dow Corning Corp. and two Japanese companies, Shin-Etsu Handotai Co. and Mitsubishi Materials Corp.
Polysilicon is a raw material used to make solar cells and semiconductor devices.

description.hltext_display: Calderone retires from sheriff's department
description.author: Brian Babcock
description.content:
Capt. Terry Calderone says there's no specific reason why he went into public safety. There was no moment of epiphany for him. It just had always felt right, even when he was a child.
So after graduating high school, Calderone moved from Southern California to the Bay Area, where he studied administration of justice at San Jose State University. Right before graduating, Calderone was offered a job with the Santa Clara County Office of the Sheriff, where he would stay for the next 31 years.
But after more than three decades of public service, five of them as captain of the sheriff's office West Valley Division, Calderone has decided to retire. He will take off his badge for the last time at the end of this month.
"It was a difficult decision. The reason it was so hard is because I still enjoy what I do for the cities. I am having a really good time trying to do the best I can for them," Calderone said.
"The biggest thing I'll miss is the interaction. And it goes two directions: It's the camaraderie and interaction with the family you develop here in the department," he said. "You develop a lot of strong bonds with individuals.
"And then it's the bond and friendships I've made here in the communities. I've made friends with people who I never could have imagined making. I met people I never thought I would have had the opportunity to meet."
The West Valley Division patrols the cities of Saratoga,yld_mgr.place_ad_here("adPosBox"); Cupertino and Los Altos Hills and unincorporated areas of the county. Calderone's position as captain essentially makes him the police chief for those cities. That perception and the responsibility that comes with it is something that Calderone has always taken seriously.
"This job is demanding. I think everyone in the sheriff's office knows that this is the most demanding position in the department because of the contract cities and the hours put in. You give up a lot of hours after your normal [workday]. You give up a lot of weekends. But they're rewarding," he said.
Calderone estimates that he has worked 12 to 15 hours a day every day for the past seven years. But it's been worth it, he said. And there are more differences between being a beat officer and a captain than just patrolling a neighborhood in a squad car.
"It's a completely different way of working. There's an expectation for you to come out and be visible, but there's also the want. I want to be out there whether it's a cultural event or a city event. There are so many different things you're invited to and are a part of," Calderone said.
The last five years have been the highlight of his career, Calderone said. And although he has great memories of patrolling some of the local cities, like Saratoga from 1984 to 1985, there are some darker moments that stick with him.
"I think the ones you never let get away from you are the ones that deal with children," he said. There is one memory in particular, he said, that is still as vivid as the day it happened in 1991.
Calderone was one of the first responders to a residential fire. He said he remembers people running out of the home and could hear screaming coming from inside. No matter how hard he tried he couldn't get through the door, he said. It turned out that there was an 8-year-old girl on the other side trying to get out. She was pulled out by firefighters, but it was too late.
"I still have the visual of seeing her come out after the fact knowing that I was right there. I still think, 'What could I have done to save her? Could I have done anything differently?' " he said.
Firefighters let him know at the time that even if he would have made it through, he would have probably died as well. That knowledge still doesn't stop him from going over the scene to this day.
Not all of Calderone's experiences were as traumatic. But some still make him shake his head when he thinks about them. He said he remembers patrolling the east side of San Jose in the early '90s, when PCP was a drug of choice for some. One day a man, high on the drug, pulled out a stop sign--pole and all--from the concrete and began swinging it at officers.
"As of late," Calderone says with a smile, "the memories have all been good."
The memories hav ealso been good for those who have worked with Calderone. Saratoga city manager Dave Anderson, along with city managers Dave Knapp of Cupertino and Carl Cahill of Los Altos Hills, hired Calderone five years ago.
Anderson said that Calderone has done exactly what they hoped he would do when they hired him: be proactive in crime prevention, provide a quick response to emergency calls and "approach the job with a modern, community-oriented policing approach."
"Working with [him] has been a pleasure. He's been able to reconcile the competing demands of working for the sheriff's office and three cities, making each city feel that he is 'their' chief of police. His attitude toward his job has always been proactive, creative and positive. We will miss working with [him] as our police chief, and wish him well in his future endeavors," Anderson said.
Calderone said he will always treasure his time working with his colleagues, city staff and residents of each community. But although he would like to stay on the job, the Green Bay Packers fan said people need to know when it's the right time to step down.
"I could be like Brett Favre and overstay my welcome, do some things and go out a little tarnished," he said. "But I'd rather go out on a high note and doing well."

description.hltext_display: Hwy 9 safety advocate learns first-hand the dangers of the roadway
description.author: Judy Peterson
description.content:
It is one of those strange ironies of life that Monte Sereno City Councilwoman Lana Malloy, a longtime advocate of improving safety on Highway 9, has learned firsthand how dangerous the roadway can be.
Malloy's husband, Dennis, was almost killed on Aug. 24 when he was bicycling on Highway 9 and was hit by a car. Dennis Malloy was in the bicycle lane heading toward Los Gatos when the accident occurred at Austin Way in front of the fire station.
"The driver was going toward Saratoga," Dennis said. "She was in the left turn lane and turned in front of me. I went over her car. I'm very lucky to be here."
The driver was charged with making an "unsafe turning movement."
The intersection of Highway 9 and Austin Way is considered one of the six most dangerous intersections in the county. Studies are under way now to find ways to improve it.
The bicycle lane Dennis was riding in is there due largely to his wife's efforts. She and another Monte Sereno resident, JoAnne Peth, founded the Highway 9 Safety Committee in 2004. Since then, the bicycle lanes have been added and funding secured for pedestrian sidewalks to be installed from Saratoga to Los Gatos.
"We'll get the sidewalks soon," Councilwoman Malloy said. "The money is in place. "We're working through the red tape with Caltrans."
Asked if she thinks Highway 9 is safer since the bike lanes went in, Malloy wavered a bit. "That's a tough question," she said. "I wasyld_mgr.place_ad_here("adPosBox"); thinking it was safer before Dennis' accident. But yes, I think it's probably safer."
Dennis says the accident, which put him in the hospital for four days, was life-changing and still causes him a lot of pain. "My spine was injured, I had three broken ribs and my shoulder is still dislocated," he said. "I have to have it operated on in January. I'm recovering, but I've got a long way to go. The doctor says my spine will never be the same."
Indeed, Mrs Malloy jokes half-heartedly that her husband is now about 2 inches shorter than he was before the accident. "But thank God he's alive," she said.
The councilwoman calls Highway 9 a "speedway," pointing to two accidents that occurred in October--one only shook up the drivers of the vehicles involved, but the other sent a motorcyclist and his passenger to the hospital. "The motorcyclist used the center lane as a passing lane," she said. "People need to be more aware of their speed. The speed limit changes six times between Los Gatos and Saratoga and the lanes change from two to two with a turn lane, to four lanes and back to two with a turn lane, then back to two as you get into Saratoga."
Since Highway 9 is a state highway, it is technically the responsibility of the CHP to police it. But Malloy says they rarely do. So the policing is left to the Los Gatos-Monte Sereno Police Department and the sheriff's department. "I don't want people to get tickets," Malloy said. "But if people know the cops are looking maybe they'll watch what they're doing."
Malloy also hopes drivers will keep in mind that originally Highway 9 was a horse and buggy road between Los Gatos and Saratoga. "The highway was not built for as much traffic as it carries today," she said. "People also need to understand that this highway is a death trap."

description.hltext_display: Katy Perry's 'magic sex tricks' keep hubby Russell Brand under her thumb
description.content:
Katy Perry's 'magic sex tricks' keep hubby Russell Brand under her thumb
Britain News.Net
Newlywed Katy Perry has revealed that she keeps her sex life with hubby Russell Brand interesting by performing 'magic tricks' in the bedroom.
But the raunchy singer's secrets are so naughty they are too X-rated to share.
"I have secrets and magic tricks, of course. I can't share them because then you'd all know. But let's just say I'm not shy. And I never wear sweats. Ever," the Daily Star quoted her as telling Grazia magazine.
Katy, 26, said her spicy antics had even helped her get Brand, 35, under the thumb, and joked: "At least it's a beautifully manicured thumb." (ANI)
Have your say on this story

event_or_fact.property: her spicy antics had even helped her get Brand, 35, under the thumb, and joked: "At least it's a beautifully manicured thumb.

description.hltext_display: Taking the mystery out of wine
description.content:
Journal photo by Tim Hynds Journal photo by Tim HyndsJerry Janssen is shown at Winestyles, his Sioux City wine shop on Friday, Oct. 29, 2010. Sioux City Journal photo by Tim Hynds
Loading…
Wine 101
THREE RED WINES TO KNOW
MERLOT
What is it: A soft, introductory red wine.
What foods can it be paired: Anything.
What is tastes like: Blackberry, plum and herbal flavors.
PINOT NOIR
What is it: Made only with "the noblest of red wine grapes," Pinot Noir is rarely blended and has no roughness.
What foods can it be paired: Grilled salmon, chicken and lamb.
What it taste like: Delicate and fresh, Pinot Noir has a very fruity taste.
CABERNET SAUVIGNON
What is it: Widely accepted as one of the world's best variety of wines, Cabernet Sauvignon is often blended with Cabernet Franc and Merlot.
What foods can it be paired: Best with simply prepared red meats.
What it tastes like: Full-bodied but firm.
FIVE WHITE WINES TO KNOW
CHARDONNAY
What is it: The most popular white grape wine, it can be sparkling or still
What foods can be paired: Fish or chicken dishes
What it tastes like: It can either be velvety with rich citrus flavors or it can be buttery with a flavor of coconut or vanilla.
RIESLING
What is it: A popular, dry white wine.
What foods can be paired: Goes well with fish, chicken and turkey.
What it tastes like: Lighter than Chardonnays, it has a fresh, sweet taste and smells like apples.
ZINFANDEL
What is it: Descended from the Croatian grape Crljenak, a Zinfandel is brawny, smooth and richly flavored.
What foods can be paired: Perfect with grilled burgers, chicken and sausage.
What it tastes like: A jammy, juicy fruitiness.
SAUVIGNON BLANC
What is it: While Chardonnay may lean towards being full-bodied, a Sauvignon Blanc is light and lithe.
What foods can be paired: Light fish, salads and green vegetables.
What it tastes like: An herbal scent, with a tart, citrus taste.
PINOT BLANC
What is it: Made with French grapes, Pinot Blanc is musky with a creamy texture.
What foods can be paired: Works well with lighter foods and cheese-based dishes.
What it tastes like: Clean, refreshing almost a neutral taste.
Can't tell a Brut from a Bordeaux when it comes to holiday bubblies?
Winestyles' Jerry Janssen feels your pain. In fact, consider him to be a Demi-sec detective when it comes to all of your pre-New Year's Eve wine-related worries.
“As younger people make the leap from beer to wine,” he said, “many of them may have questions.”
That's why the wines at Janssen's Lakeport Commons store are organized by group, to make things easier for both the experienced connoisseur or the connoisseur wannabe.
For instance, all of the sparkling wines are organized in one place. Yet, not all of Janssen's bubbly can be called “Champagne,” which is a very specific type of French sparkling wine.
“Champagne refers to the region of France where the grape is grown,” he explained. “The people in that region carefully guard the right to use the name 'Champagne' on their bottles.”
That's why sparkling wines made outside of the French region – specifically American sparkling wines – boast the designation “methode champenoise,” which means the grapes may not come from Champagne but traditional, old world methods were used in its preparation.
“In fact, some of our most popular sparkling wines are not Champagne,” Janssen said. “They can come from many parts of the world.”
Likewise, red and white wines can go from light and crispy to bold and full-bodied.
“For someone uncertain of white wines, a dry and light Riesling might be recommended,” Janssen said. “But for someone more experienced, this wine may prove to be too sweet.”
A good “introductory” red wine might be a Merlot, which he said can be paired with any type of food because of its “relative softness.”
Janssen also said quality wines doesn't have to be expensive.
“The majority of our wines fall in the $15 to $25 range,” he said. “We also have an 'If You Insist' section for wines that are more expensive.”
More than anything, Janssen suggests experimenting with different types of wine.
“Everyone has a different palette and a palette does change over time,” he said. “I'm certain we have a wine that is perfect for even the most discriminating of tastes.”

event_or_fact.property: quality wines doesn't have to be expensive

?many of them may have questions.? That's why the wines at Janssen's Lakeport Commons store are organized by group, to make things easier for both the experienced connoisseur or the connoisseur wannabe

description.hltext_display: 12月21日操盘必读：两市重大消息全览
description.content:
作者：simuba 来源：私募吧 发表时间：2010-12-21
（四）地域动态/有限利好 上证《中俄原油管道试投运成功 中国将每年新增1500万吨原油》“令业界期待已久的管输俄罗斯原油终于抵达中国境内。....
第一部分：早间要闻速览
开盘必读：
证券要闻：
公司要闻：
大盘分析：
“朝韩危机”触发震荡 A股“上下两难”
A股神经脆弱 但仍不具备持续下跌条件
资金炒作朝韩半岛 紧张局势只是砸盘借口
热点板块：
“一号文件”胎动 四农业股涨停预热行情
传媒板块：多“财”多艺 三因素支持板块走强
朝韩局势导“火” 军工股逆市逞强
个股聚焦：
永辉超市高换手率背后：机构成买卖主角
*ST钒钛股价逼近行权价 巨资博弈今见分晓
汤臣倍健闪电预增 各路机构狂买股价走高
第二部分：热点新闻解读
叶剑
-----笔者按：短线股指继续震荡为主。操作上继续紧盯跨年度可能有高比例分红送股的潜力品种中的新兴产业、成长行业。
（一）行业动态/局部利好
上证《农产品涨势未退 保供给或成中央政策主题》“农产品价格的持续上涨已经引起决策层的高度重视，增加供给抑制价格上涨有望成为即将召开的中央农村工作会议的重要议题。国家统计局20日公布200个主产县主要农产品价格变动情况显示，在12月1日到10日之间，包括籼稻、粳稻、小麦、玉米、大豆、油菜籽、花生仁、生猪、活牛、活羊等等在内的一系列农产品价格都有不同程度的上涨。记者从农业部获悉，为期两天的中央农村工作会议将于今日召开。会议将明确2011年中央农村工作的目标和任务，并形成2011年中央一号文件的主要内容。而如何通过控制农产品价格来抑制通胀，袁钢明表示，国家这次管理通货膨胀的一个重点是控制投机、流通领域中的炒作问题。”
简评:农业板块的新股，可以进一步挖掘。
（二）突发事件/利空为主兼备局部利好
上证《韩实弹射击 亚太股市轻微“受伤”》“周一午后，韩国在延坪岛进行的实弹射击训练牵动了市场神经，但“杀伤力”明显下降了一个级别。周一的亚太股市几乎全线收低，但主要股指普遍脱离了盘中低点，跌幅大多低于1%。随后开盘的欧洲股市则普遍高开，未受明显影响，避险指标美元不涨反跌。朝鲜方面在20日晚些时候宣布，“不值得”对韩国的“军事挑衅”作出应对。随着韩国将进行射击训练的消息不断在市场发酵，周一的亚太股市开盘后即普陷低迷，韩国本土基准股指一度大跌1.5%，跌穿2000点的整数关口；中国内地A股盘中跌近3%，港股跌1.4%，日股跌1.2%。韩元兑美元一度大跌1.7%。”
简评：朝韩大打不起来，炮击事件只是一个插曲性质的事件，影响是短暂的。其对于军工股的刺激也作为短线看待、及时了结为宜。
（三）行业动态/利好
上证《我国探月工程嫦娥二号任务圆满成功》“中共中央、国务院和中央军委20日上午在人民大会堂举行大会，隆重庆祝我国探月工程嫦娥二号任务圆满成功。中共中央总书记、国家主席、中央军委主席胡锦涛发表重要讲话。他强调，嫦娥二号任务圆满成功，是我国探月工程取得的又一成就，是我们建设创新型国家取得的又一成果，是中国人民攀登世界科技高峰的又一壮举，谱写了中华民族自强不息、锐意创新的壮丽篇章。这一重大成就，对推动我国航天事业发展、引领我国科技创新，对激励全党全军全国各族人民意气风发地投身改革开放和社会主义现代化事业具有十分重要的意义。”
简评：航空航天业等新兴产业，未来还有发展的空间，可继续在其中寻找机会。

description.hltext_display: 警局前討債 黑幫潑漆撒冥紙(台視)
description.content: 新竹縣警方破獲一起詐賭集團暴力討債案，嫌犯鎖定一名文具行負責人，以幫朋友慶生為理由，將被害人騙到KTV趁機灌酒，再設局詐賭，被害人久下賭債還不出來，就到文具店撒冥紙潑漆討債，由於文具店斜對面就是橫山分局，警方大為震驚，在佈線三個月後逮捕五名嫌犯，另外還有四人在逃。

description.hltext_display: Li’s Oriental Plaza Said to Plan Yuan Hong Kong IPO
description.author: Bei Hu and Kelvin Wong
description.content:
By Bei Hu and Kelvin Wong
(Updates with Cheung Kong share in seventh paragraph and adds Li history in ninth, 14th, 15th.)
Dec. 22 (Bloomberg) -- Li Ka-shing, Hong Kongs richest man, is preparing what may be the first yuan-denominated initial public offering in the city in the first half of 2011, said two people with knowledge of the matter.
Li, 82, hired Citic Securities International Co. to lead the sale of more than 10 billion yuan ($1.5 billion) of shares in a real estate investment trust backed by the Oriental Plaza development in Beijing, said one of the people, who declined to be identified because the information is private. HSBC Holdings Plc will help arrange the offering, the people said.
Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. Chief Executive Officer Charles Li has proposed allowing yuan-denominated share sales in the city. Chinese-currency deposits at Hong Kong banks swelled to a record 217.1 billion yuan in October, according to Hong Kong Monetary Authority data. If reaction to the IPO is good, it may very well create a trend for other Hong Kong developers to follow, said Lee Wee Liat, a Hong Kong-based analyst at Samsung Securities Ltd.
Companies have sold more than 62 billion yuan of bonds denominated in the Chinese currency in Hong Kong since 2007, according to a Dec. 20 Bank of China (Hong Kong) Ltd. statement.
Winnie Cheong, a Hong Kong-based spokeswoman for Lis Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd., didnt immediately return phone calls seeking comment. Joyce Ho, a spokeswoman at Citic Securities International in Hong Kong, said the firm doesnt comment on market rumors. Maggie Cheung, an HSBC spokeswoman in the city, declined to comment. Chinese-language newspaper Hong Kong Economic Times reported Lis plan earlier today.
Cheung Kong shares rose 3.4 percent to HK$120.20 as of 3:57 p.m. in Hong Kong trading.
Cheung Kong, the developer controlled by Li, owns 33.4 percent of the Oriental Plaza and Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., 49.9 percent owned by Cheung Kong, has 18 percent, according to the companies 2009 annual report.
Li built the company into Hong Kongs second-biggest developer by market value after he began buying property in the city in 1967 when riots tied to Chinas Cultural Revolution caused land prices in the city to collapse.
Lorraine Chan, a spokeswoman for the Hong Kong bourse, declined to comment on the proposed offering. The exchange is ready to support the listing, trading and clearing of RMB- denominated products in Hong Kong, she said in an e-mailed response to questions, referring to renminbi, the yuans other name. Hong Kong should promote yuan-denominated IPOs, Joseph Yam, former chief executive of the HKMA, said in a public lecture in the city today. Hong Kong is ready to develop a yuan IPO market, Yam said.
Oriental Plaza, covering an area of 100,000 square meters (1.1 million square feet), is situated along Beijings Changan Avenue in the heart of the city. It consists of eight grade-A office towers, a shopping mall, a Grand Hyatt Hotel, and serviced apartments, according to its website.
Shareholders will be selling existing stock in the Li- backed REIT, said one of the people. More banks may be added to the sale, the people said. This will provide an alternative funding channel for Cheung Kongs development in mainland China, said Samsungs Lee. Clearly in the next five to seven years mainland China instead of Hong Kong will be the main growth engine for a developer the size of Cheung Kong. After arriving in Hong Kong as a refugee from China in 1940, Li swept factory floors to survive during the Japanese World War II occupation of the city between 1941 and 1945. After the war, he opened a plastic-flower factory and then started buying real estate in the city.
Li was listed as the worlds 14th-richest person in March by Forbes magazine, compared with 16th a year earlier, after his wealth increased to $21 billion.
--With Eva Woo in Beijing and Hanny Wan in Hong Kong. Editors: Andreea Papuc, Russell Ward
To contact the reporter on this story: Bei Hu in Hong Kong at bhu5@bloomberg.net; Kelvin Wong at kwong40@bloomberg.net; Eva Woo in Beijing at ewoo9@bloomberg.net
To contact the editor responsible for this story: Andreea Papuc at apapuc1@bloomberg.net

company.name: Hong Kong Economic Times Holdings Ltd.

description.hltext_display: Personeller Aderlass macht Reform notwendig
description.content:
Günter Brinkis
Der Vizepräsident des Westfälischen Handballverbandes ist dort zuständig für den Bereich Spieltechnik und genau in dieser Funktion will er zu Beginn des nächsten Jahres eine Kommission gründen, die sich mit dieser Thematik eingehend befasst. Die Tendenz, dass wir weniger Mannschaften haben, geht weiter. Die Geburtenraten stehen doch fest, daran wird sich nichts ändern, sagt Brinkis, der davon ausgeht, dass in den nächsten fünf Jahren erneut 100 Teams weniger am Spielbetrieb teilnehmen.
Das Problem dabei: die Kreise bluten nach den bisherigen Regeln des Spielbetriebs aus. Sie müssen dafür sorgen, dass in den übergeordneten Ligen des Verbands Westfalen stets genug Mannschaften spielen. Und so haben wir auf Kreisebene schnell deutlich weniger Ligen, so Brinkis.Eine Lösung des Problems, das natürlich für die Vereine auch negative finanzielle Folgen hat, muss her. Eine Möglichkeit, mit der sich Brinkis auch schon intensiv befasst hat: Die sechs dem WHV angehörenden Bezirksligen werden abgeschafft und dafür Kreis-Oberligen eingeführt. Die würden organisatorisch vom jeweiligen Kreis geführt. Kurze Wege und damit niedrigere Kosten, dazu einige neu gewonnene Mannschaften auf höherem Niveau. Die aktuellen Bezirksligisten sollen nicht glauben, sie würden absteigen, sondern sie spielen eben in einer anderen Klasse, weiß Brinkis, der bekanntlich auch im Kreis Hellweg als zweiter Vorsitzender tätig ist.
Im dadurch verschlankten Verband Westfalen wären in dem Fall nur noch die Landes-, Verbands- und Oberligen organisiert. Der Meister der Kreis-Oberligen, von denen es insgesamt zwölf geben würde, steigt direkt in die Landesliga auf.
Zudem werden die Ligen aufgestockt. Bei den Männern würden dann 16 und bei den Frauen, bei denen der Verlust von Mannschaften nicht ganz so dramatisch wie bei den Männern ist, 14 Teams pro Liga um Meisterschaftspunkte kämpfen.Wir müssen eben sehen, dass wir unsere Sportart so interessant wie möglich gestalten. Dabei sind finanzielle Aspekte nicht einfach auszublenden, sagt Brinkis. Wir stehen mit dem Problem ja nicht allein da. Beim Fußball gibt es doch auch Überlegungen, Teamstärken in bestimmten Bereichen von elf auf neun Spieler zu reduzieren.Neu wäre die Abschaffung der Bezirksligen nicht. In den Verbänden Niederrhein und Mittelrhein gibt es die schon seit einiger Zeit nicht mehr. Ob und wenn ja, wie die Reform durchgesetzt wird, ist noch völlig offen. Auch ein möglicher Zeitpunkt wurde noch nicht diskutiert. Klar ist diesbezüglich nur, dass eine Neuregelung von einer Saison auf die nächste durchgeführt werden muss. Ein schleichender Prozess, wie bei der Strukturreform vor einigen Jahren, ist nicht möglich, sagt Brinkis.Am 29. Januar treffen sich die 24 Kreisvorsitzenden in Dortmund. Einziges Thema dort: die Zukunftsperspektiven des WHV.
